title: The Second Coming of Eugene V. Debs
summary: Bernie Sanders says he's another FDR, but he's more closely related to the early 20th-century labor leader who ran for the presidency five times as a Socialist.. Flirting with guests and invoking Nazi analogies to describe primary results has reportedly cost Chris Matthews his job as host of MSNBC's "Hardball." Fair enough, but know that the show's audience is also losing that increasingly rare species: a political commentator who is willing to tell the party base what he really thinks, even if it isn't what the base wants to hear. And in that respect, the timing of Mr. Matthews's exit is unfortunate.

title: Tornadoes Kill at Least 25 in Tennessee
summary: 'Nashville is hurting' after twisters tear through area, causing widespread damage. Tornadoes ripped through Tennessee Tuesday, killing at least 25 people as the twisters carved a path through scenic mountain communities and razed venues in a trendy Nashville neighborhood.

title: Confronting Sexual Assault on Campus
summary: Students discuss the #MeToo era and next steps at college.. Editor's note: This Future View is about the #MeToo movement and sexual assault on campus. For next week we'll ask, "Is there a better way for parties to nominate presidential candidates? How would you transform or improve the American process?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before March 10. The best responses will be published that night.

title: Israel's New Diplomatic Moment
summary: Trump's peace plan calls attention to Palestinian division and the collapse of the Arab political order.. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declared victory in Monday's Israeli election, the third since April, following two inconclusive results. Although Mr. Netanyahu may be frustrated in his attempt to form a government, his Likud Party won 36 seats, a strong showing. During the campaign, Likud candidates stressed their support for President Trump's "Peace to Prosperity" plan, unveiled in January. The plan won't bring peace between Israelis and Palestinians, but it may expose deeper processes of change under way in the Middle East. It could even advance those changes-and Israel stands to benefit.

title: The OB-GYNs Who Play Politics With Women's Lives
summary: Abortion is more important than safety to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.. As the Supreme Court gets ready to hear another abortion case, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists-the specialty's main professional organization-has weighed in with a friend-of-the-court brief. ACOG is offering a medically unsound recommendation in the furtherance of its extreme position on abortion.

title: Covid-19 May Have You Working At Home
summary: Preventing the virus's spread will likely require 'social distancing' tactics like canceling events.. The numbers don't tell the whole story. Nine Americans have died of Covid-19, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirms more than 100 cases in 15 states. But there are probably already several thousand Americans who have been infected. For now, the average person's risk is low in a nation of 330 million, but that may soon change. The highest risk is for those who live in regional hot zones such as Washington state or Northern California.

title: How to Shop for a Pandemic
summary: We're well-stocked, but our local store reports a run on whipped cream.. New York

title: A Corona-Sanders Panic Ebbs?
summary: The epidemiology of a new virus collides with the economics of cable news.. Be afraid, be very afraid-of the flu, not the coronavirus.

title: Joe Biden Gets Back in the Ring
summary: He is swinging with vigor as votes from the Super Tuesday contests are tallied.. A week, it is often said, is an eternity in politics-rarely more so than for Joe Biden in the past seven days. It was only last Wednesday that Rep. Jim Clyburn, respected throughout the Democratic Party and revered in his home state of South Carolina, endorsed Mr. Biden, setting the stage for the former vice president's smashing victory Saturday in the Palmetto State.

title: 'Not to Scale' Review: Both Ends of the Telescope
summary: How to take massive problems and shrink them down to size, as well as connect grass-roots decisions to the grand scheme of things.. 'Does it scale?" This is almost the first question anyone asks about anything new-startups, technologies, ideas. It's OK to start small, but bigger is almost always assumed to be better, or at least more profitable. "Scale" comes from the Latin "scala," which means "ladder," and we all know it's better to climb up than to move down in the world. Yet lost in this formulation is a sense of what's appropriate, of what actually works. That feeling of balance is what Jamer Hunt seeks to restore in "Not to Scale: How the Small Becomes Large, the Large Becomes Unthinkable, and the Unthinkable Becomes Possible."

title: Erik Nordstrom Named Sole CEO of Nordstrom
summary: Appointment ends an unusual structure, but keeps control with the family. Nordstrom Inc. named Erik Nordstrom as its sole chief executive, ending an unusual shared management structure and keeping the retailer's leadership in the hands of the founding family.

title: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Posts Lower Revenue
summary: HPE said it no longer expects revenue growth this fiscal year as epidemic worsens component shortage. Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co. cut its free-cash flow projections for the year, citing a supply-chain disruption that was aggravated by the coronavirus epidemic, and said it no longer expects revenue to increase this year.

title: The Fed Cut Is the Deepest for Banks and Insurers
summary: Top U.S. lenders take direct hit from central bank's emergency move; shares have fallen more steeply than broader market over past week. Already among the worst performers in the market's swoon over the past week, banks took a direct hit Tuesday from the Federal Reserve's emergency rate cut.

title: A Career Filled With High Notes
summary: Michael Tilson Thomas, now in the final season of his 25 years at the helm of the San Francisco Symphony, has left a profound imprint on both the orchestra and the city..

title: Energy Shares Suffer the Most From Coronavirus Fears
summary: The sector's stocks are closely tied to crude prices, and the epidemic has significantly tamped down oil demand. Worries about fallout from the coronavirus are pummeling already-battered energy stocks, upending a nascent recovery that followed a spate of better-than-expected earnings and dividend increases and signaling the magnitude of investors' concern about the virus's effect on crude demand.

title: Westchester Attorney Is New York's Second Coronavirus Patient
summary: Bronx private school where one of the patient's children attends is closed. A Westchester County attorney became the second person in New York to test positive for the new coronavirus, officials said Tuesday, leading to the closure of a Bronx private school attended by one of his children, the halt of services at a synagogue and the testing of several people at his Midtown Manhattan law firm.

title: Capitalism, Socialism and Haley's Comment
summary: As U.S. ambassador to the U.N., Gov. Haley got to see firsthand the destructive work of socialism in many countries around the world.. While Nikki Haley effectively advocates capitalism, she unfortunately only very briefly touches on the cause for our (or my generation's, at least) embrace of socialism-education ("This Is No Time to Go Wobbly on Capitalism," op-ed, Feb. 27). I received both public and private educations, and while they had their differences, they shared one major similarity; never, in all my years in the American education system, did I ever have a history or social-studies teacher who provided a conservative context without derision, let alone detached bias. Free markets were discussed, but only as tools preferred by the most avaricious in our society.

title: More Coding Instruction Would Be Helpful
summary: Right now, only 45% of high schools across the country offer computer science as an option, let alone a requirement. We're not even keeping up with demand from students and parents for these classes.. "Should All Children Learn to Code by the End of High School?" (Journal Report, Feb. 24) is a great question, but wildly premature. Right now, only 45% of high schools across the country offer computer science as an option, let alone a requirement. We're not even keeping up with demand from students and parents for these classes.

title: The Federal Reserve Should Just Stick to Its Mandates
summary: The Federal Reserve has wandered away from its dual mandates of price stability and full employment, greenlighting any policy action it deems appropriate.. "A central bank's primary job is to offset major disturbances of the economy," says Kevin Warsh in "The Fed Can't Wait to Respond to the Coronavirus" (op-ed, Feb. 27). In one sentence Mr. Warsh illuminates how far the Federal Reserve has wandered away from its dual mandates of price stability and full employment, greenlighting any policy action it deems appropriate.

title: City Halts Court Order to Chop Much of West-Side Condo Tower

summary: Suit follows similar legal action against New York Times, both related to articles referencing the campaign's interactions with Russia. title: Stocks Slide Despite Fed Move
summary: Dow closes nearly 800 points lower; Treasury yields drop again despite Federal Reserve move. U.S. stocks and government bond yields slid Tuesday after the Federal Reserve's interest-rate cut failed to assuage money managers fearful of the economic fallout from the coronavirus epidemic.

title: Fed Cuts Interest Rates by Half Percentage Point
summary: Central bank lowers federal-funds rate range to 1% to 1.25% in its first between-meeting move since the financial crisis. summary: Benchmark rate keeps dropping as investors look to buy safer assets and the Federal Reserve reduces its short-term target. title: Alain de Botton: Why Our Appetites for Faith Are Legitimate
summary: But we haven't successfully replaced the institutions that provide it: "[S]cholars and researchers and curators have been scared of the emotional stickiness involved". "In the 19th century, when the world was rapidly secularizing, the rallying cry was that culture would replace scripture. You may not be reading the Bible, but you're going to read the classics. You may not be going to church, but you'll go to the museum. That idea is not working out. If you showed up at any of these institutions and said, 'I'm looking to work out the meaning of life; I'm looking to know how to cope with my finitude in an infinite and awesome universe,' they would be calling you an ambulance. The appetite's legitimate. We need to be awed, to be relativized, to be set within a greater context. But scholars and researchers and curators have been scared of the emotional stickiness involved in trying to deal with their audiences' deeper needs. We must try to rescue some of what is wise and helpful and useful from religion, even as it no longer seems to many of us to be true."

title: Some International Test Sites for College Admissions Are Shut on Virus Fears
summary: Students in China and elsewhere are having to postpone entrance exams for U.S. universities. Several college-admissions tests including the SAT, ACT, GMAT and Toefl have been postponed at some international locations amid the spread of the novel coronavirus, potentially weighing on the volume of international student applications that U.S. universities receive.

title: Down-Ballot Democrats Turn to Joe Biden
summary: Some Democrats have warned that Sen. Bernie Sanders could hurt Democrats running in competitive races. This item first appeared in the Capital Journal newsletter. Read today's full newsletter here or sign up here for daily updates in your inbox.

title: Stocks to Watch: Kohl's, Target, Thermo Fisher, Apple
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Tuesday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Tuesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours.; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: The Six Best-Designed Items of March
summary: Our design- and fashion-minded editors on the most compelling happenings, items and events of the month. In 1801, Swiss-French watchmaker Abraham-Louis Breguet patented the complex tourbillon, which places a watch's escapement in a separate rotating cage-thereby reducing the gravitational effects that can hinder accurate timekeeping. The Breguet Classique Extra-Thin Tourbillon Squelette 5395 showcases this centuries-old mechanism, named after the French word for whirlwind, behind a glass face. Housed within a three-millimeter-thick guilloche plate, the case is made of 18-karat rose gold. Breguet watch, $225,200, breguet.com

title: Swiss Re Picks UBS CEO Ermotti as Next Chairman
summary: Banker is stepping down after nine years leading Switzerland's largest lender by assets. Sergio Ermotti will become chairman of Swiss Re , one of the world's biggest insurers, after he steps down as chief executive of UBS Group AG later this year.

title: China Decries U.S. Restrictions on News Agencies
summary: Move signals possible escalation of tensions between the two countries over working conditions for journalists. BEIJING-Chinese officials on Tuesday accused the U.S. government of hypocrisy and hinted at countermeasures after Washington capped the number of Chinese nationals that can work for Chinese news outlets in the U.S., signaling a possible escalation of tensions between the two countries over working conditions for journalists.

title: At Heart of Europe's Biggest Outbreak, Some Long for Normal Life
summary: Italy was quick to impose quarantine measures, but some want looser policy to reopen businesses and resume social life.

title: China Tightens Coronavirus Restrictions to Shield Beijing
summary: Capital acts to protect itself as other Chinese cities ease limits, freeing Beijing workers to return. BEIJING-While telling most of the world's second-biggest economy to resume work, Chinese President Xi Jinping has singled out two regions that he says should prioritize coronavirus containment. One is the province at the center of the epidemic. The other is Beijing.

title: Coronavirus Selloff Reveals Hidden Mechanics of Financial Markets
summary: Gold and yen are among the assets that have performed unexpectedly, revealing how market structures have changed. You only learn who has been swimming naked when the tide goes out, Warren Buffett famously wrote in a shareholder letter. As volatility has soared during the past two weeks, some asset classes have started to show a little more skin, and interesting wrinkles.

title: China's Property Market Has Seized Up. Bondholders Aren't Fazed.
summary: Creditors reckon big developers can tough out virus-related disruption, and think official support could help. Even as home sales in China have dried up because of the coronavirus epidemic, international bond investors are keeping faith with major real-estate groups.

title: This Time, Trade Slowdown May Hurt for Banks
summary: The novel coronavirus is a much bigger threat than the trade war was. Banks' cross-border trading businesses actually improved as tariffs went up and trade wars loomed. The novel coronavirus won't be so accommodating.

title: Thermo Fisher to Buy Diagnostic Company for $10.1 Billion
summary: Qiagen has been developing a test to detect the coronavirus, which is currently being evaluated at four Chinese hospitals. Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. agreed to pay about $10.1 billion for Qiagen NV, a molecular diagnostics company, bulking up in the field of infectious-disease testing.

title: Lawmakers Push Again for Info on Google Collecting Patient Data
summary: Sens. Blumenthal, Cassidy and Warren say questions remain unanswered on the tech giant's health-care project known as 'Project Nightingale'. A bipartisan trio of U.S. senators pushed again for answers on Google's controversial "Project Nightingale," saying the search giant evaded requests for details on its far-reaching data tie-up with health giant Ascension.

title: Market-Beating Bank CEOs Are a Rare Breed
summary: Most of the superstar bosses of big European lenders have failed to outperform. The search for their successors needn't be so hard.. European banks on the hunt for superstar chief executives might be overcomplicating things. The data suggests they should think local and low-key.

title: Olympics Could Be Delayed; Officials Want Starting Gun Fired on Time
summary: 'We are doing all we can to ensure that the Games go ahead as planned,' Seiko Hashimoto says. TOKYO-Tokyo's contract to host the Olympics might allow for the Games to be delayed until later this year, but organizers are focused on ensuring that they go ahead as planned despite the coronavirus epidemic, a Japanese minister said.

title: Bedding Brand Brooklinen Raises $50 Million From Summit Partners
summary: Startup says it will use cash to accelerate investments in retail, other areas. Brooklinen Inc., a startup that sells luxury bedding and other home goods online, has raised $50 million to open more of its own stores, secure new wholesale distribution partnerships and enter international markets.

title: Companies Find Ways to Keep Their Annual Reports From Being a Bore
summary: Videos, graphics and other elements can provide information in ways that engage and go beyond what regulators request. When German chemicals maker Covestro AG began drafting its 2019 annual report in August, executives opted for a change. Instead of producing a text-heavy report, the company decided to publish a digital version with video messages, interactive graphics and even a quiz.

title: Parents Track Teen Drivers (and Sometimes Vice Versa)
summary: Apps allow parents and insurers to track teen drivers, though sometimes it backfires. The time when teenagers get behind the wheel is perhaps the most harrowing of parenthood. My kids are still years away from this, but I'm already hoping self-driving cars will be ubiquitous by then. Until that happens, parents have another option: monitoring their teens' road smarts-or lack thereof-through apps.

title: Insulin Giant Aims to Unlock Elusive Obesity-Drug Market
summary: Novo Nordisk sees a multibillion-dollar opportunity despite skepticism from doctors, patients, insurance companies.

title: 'Every Little Bit Matters': Democrats Hunt for Super Tuesday Votes
summary: The majority of delegates will be apportioned based on results in congressional districts or state Senate districts. From Maine to California, Tuesday's presidential primaries in 14 states span the nation waiting to be won. Yet the biggest voting day of the nominating season is in many ways more like a series of local elections where candidates can earn delegates, even if they can't win a whole state.

title: Honeywell to Roll Out Quantum Computer
summary: JPMorgan has signed up as first public user for what Honeywell says will be world's most powerful quantum machine. Industrial conglomerate Honeywell International Inc. said Tuesday that it plans to introduce an early-stage quantum computer for commercial experiments within about three months, with JPMorgan Chase & Co. as the first public user.

title: Tim Cook and Apple Bet Everything on China. Then Coronavirus Hit.
summary: Quarantines, tariffs and slumping sales have caused agitation about the company's strategy of assembling most of its products there. Long before the coronavirus struck, Apple Inc.'s operations team began raising concerns about the technology giant's dependency on China.

title: Chinese Markets Are Proving Resilient to Coronavirus Turmoil
summary: A large base of individual investors, supportive policy and relatively low valuations have helped. The novel coronavirus epidemic began in China and has shaken markets around the world. One surprising standout: Chinese stocks.

title: Coronavirus Drives Interest Rates Lower in Australia
summary: Central bank warns epidemic has clouded near-term outlook for global economy. SYDNEY-Central banks world-wide are signaling a new effort to cushion the impact of the coronavirus on the global economy, with Australia cutting interest rates in a bid to maintain its 28-year streak without a recession.

title: New York's First Coronavirus Patient Is Health-Care Worker
summary: Woman, 39 years old, showed symptoms of disease after returning from Iran. New York's first patient infected with coronavirus is a health-care worker who showed symptoms of disease only after returning from Iran, officials said Monday.

title: The Best Thing That's Ever Happened to Roasted Sweet Potatoes
summary: We all need some comfort right now-perhaps some outright indulgence. This recipe delivers both.. EVERY ONCE IN A WHILE an ingredient comes along that really knocks chefs off their feet. In recent years, 'nduja, the spreadable Italian sausage, has shown up on more and more menus across the country, lending gorgeous fatty richness and a spicy kick to everything from charcuterie boards to pasta sauces. At Rolf and Daughters in Nashville, Philip Krajeck has found a particularly appealing application for the stuff. He mixes 'nduja with butter and slathers it on a whole roasted sweet potato. The salty-sweet-spicy combination is sensational.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: The Best Thing That's Ever Happened to Roasted Sweet Potatoes
summary: We all need some comfort right now-perhaps some outright indulgence. This recipe delivers both.. EVERY ONCE IN A WHILE an ingredient comes along that really knocks chefs off their feet. In recent years, 'nduja, the spreadable Italian sausage, has shown up on more and more menus across the country, lending gorgeous fatty richness and a spicy kick to everything from charcuterie boards to pasta sauces. At Rolf and Daughters in Nashville, Philip Krajeck has found a particularly appealing application for the stuff. He mixes 'nduja with butter and slathers it on a whole roasted sweet potato. The salty-sweet-spicy combination is sensational.

title: Moderate Democrats Consolidate Around Biden Ahead of Super Tuesday
summary: Biden and Bloomberg both pitch themselves as the candidate capable of stopping front-runner Bernie Sanders. The moderate wing of the Democratic Party swiftly consolidated around Joe Biden's candidacy ahead of Super Tuesday, as a trio of the former vice president's competitors, Pete Buttigieg, Amy Klobuchar and Beto O'Rourke, joined forces to endorse him Monday.

title: Klobuchar Ends Presidential Campaign, Will Endorse Biden
summary: The Minnesota senator will endorse former Vice President Joe Biden. Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar formally ended her bid for the presidency and endorsed former Vice President Joe Biden on Monday, one day before the biggest day of Democratic primary voting so far.

title: U.S. Coronavirus Death Toll Climbs to Six as Virus Spreads World-Wide
summary: Four new deaths linked to the coronavirus have been reported in Washington state. Washington state emerged as the U.S. center of a spreading coronavirus fight Monday, as state health officials reported four additional deaths there and 18 confirmed cases and multiple schools closed for disinfection.

title: Vatican Researchers to Help Investigate Clerical Abuse
summary: Researchers to hear testimony from abuse victims at the request of the Mexican church. MEXICO CITY-The Vatican's two senior sex crimes researchers will be dispatched to Mexico in late March to help investigate clerical abuse following the latest revelations in a long-running crisis involving a Mexican order known as the Legion of Christ.

title: Colombia Upholds Abortion Laws as Legalization Battle Shifts to Argentina
summary: Both countries have become the focus of activists working to loosen Latin America's strict laws against the procedure. BOGOTÁ, Colombia-Colombia's top court Monday opted not to expand abortion rights but campaigners for the procedure now look to Argentina, where the new leftist president said he will propose a legalization bill to Congress by next week.

title: Chris Matthews to Leave MSNBC Amid Controversy, Sanders Remarks
summary: Cable channel's decision to release 74-year-old anchor from contract was mutual, according to source. MSNBC "Hardball" host Chris Matthews announced on air Monday that he was leaving the network, days after being accused of making inappropriate flirtatious comments to a guest and comparing Sen. Bernie Sanders's victory in the Nevada caucuses to the World War II Nazi takeover of France.

title: Israel Election Exit Polls Put Netanyahu Ahead
summary: Prime minister appears to have edge over rival Benny Gantz to form government after a prolonged deadlock. TEL AVIV-Exit polls for Israel's third national election in less than a year suggested that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was leading challenger Benny Gantz and close to securing a majority in Israel's parliament.

title: Trump to Meet With GOP Lawmakers Amid Fight Over U.S. Spying Powers
summary: Privacy hawks Rand Paul and Mike Lee to attend meeting, as well as Attorney General William Barr. WASHINGTON-President Trump will meet Tuesday with a group of Republicans who are on different sides of a fight over whether to curtail the government's spying powers when Congress enacts must-pass legislation to extend some expiring surveillance authorities.

title: Biden vs. Sanders? Yes, But What About Chuck D vs. Flavor Flav.
summary: The Public Enemy pioneers trade barbs over whether money or a Sanders rally led to their falling out. It was pretty clear the 2020 presidential election was going to be divisive. Who would have guessed it would contribute to the splintering of one of the most famous political groups in hip-hop history?

title: Constitutional Case of the Year
summary: Brett Kavanaugh gets his moment on the separation of powers.. The Supreme Court hears what may be its most important case of the year on Tuesday, and don't stop reading because it concerns the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. This one goes to the heart of the separation of powers and whether the administrative state is accountable to the people.

title: All Tom Steyer's Money
summary: He spent a quarter billion dollars but won no delegates.. Tom Steyer spent more than $250 million of his own money running for President-enough to buy 6,200 Teslas-before dropping out Saturday after a distant third-place finish in South Carolina. His money didn't win him a single delegate.

title: The Stop Sanders Moment
summary: Buttigieg and Klobuchar back Biden ahead of Super Tuesday.. Amy Klobuchar's decision to drop out of the Democratic presidential race and endorse Joe Biden could be a turning point as the party tries to consolidate around a candidate to defeat Bernie Sanders. Sen. Klobuchar's announcement comes a day after her debate-stage nemesis Pete Buttigieg also exited. He reportedly will also endorse Mr. Biden.

title: Firefighters In Isolation After Responding to Nursing Home With Virus Outbreak
summary: Nineteen firefighters are under isolation after being sent to Kirkland, Wash., nursing home that is at center of coronavirus outbreak. Firefighter Jessica Brassfield donned gloves as she entered the Life Care Center of Kirkland, a nursing home in Kirkland, Wash., not long after midnight Wednesday.

title: In Colorado, Independents Might Determine Democratic Victor
summary: While Sanders leads polls, state's shift from caucuses to open primary in which independents can vote raises uncertainty. John Brackney, a former county commissioner from the Denver suburbs and registered independent, will be able to do something for the first time on Tuesday: cast a vote in a Democratic presidential primary.

title: Puerto Rico Utility Deal Stumbles, Shaking Muni Investors
summary: Municipal bondholders turned bullish on Puerto Rico's troubled utility just as elected officials vetoed a politically unpopular repayment plan. Municipal bond buyers thought Puerto Rico was on the cusp of restructuring its troubled power monopoly on their preferred terms. Now they aren't so sure, as government leaders harden their stance against hiking electricity rates to pay off billions of dollars in debt.

title: Capital Is Part of the Coronavirus Cure
summary: And markets have historically been quick to recover from pandemic threats.. U.S. stocks capped their worst week since 2008 Friday amid fears that the coronavirus will become a pandemic. Though markets rallied Monday on expectations that central banks will slash interest rates, the Nasdaq was still down nearly 9% from its record close of 9817.18 on Feb. 19.

title: 'On Diversity' Review: Conformity Rebranded
summary: Are we becoming more and more like each other? If so, we need a clearer idea of what we mean by 'diversity.'. There is something deeply amiss about the way the word "diversity" is used in American culture, but it's not easy to describe what that something is. That human diversity is a good thing is self-evident, but do its cheerleaders care about diversity for its own sake? Sometimes you suspect that what they really want is sameness. On Staten Island this week, the upcoming St. Patrick's Day Parade is the object of outrage because its organizers have not approved a gay and lesbian contingent to march under its own banner. Boycotters cannot abide the thought of a public event in which older opinions prevail in any way. What they want is . . . diversity.

title: Novartis Unit to Pay $195 Million in Generic-Drug Price-Fixing Case
summary: Sandoz admitted it was guilty of participating in several conspiracies to rig bids, fix prices. WASHINGTON- Novartis AG's Sandoz subsidiary will pay a $195 million criminal penalty for fixing prices on generic drugs, the Justice Department said Monday.

title: Look Out, World-It's Sanders
summary: If he makes it to the White House, Iran, Russia and Latin leftists will benefit.. What would a Bernie Sanders presidency mean for U.S. foreign policy? Observers around the world are beginning to ask this question as the socialist senator leads his rivals for the Democratic nomination. The answers are disquieting. To the extent that a Sanders administration is able to implement the policies Mr. Sanders advocated in his major foreign-policy addresses in 2017 and 2018, and that his foreign-policy adviser Matt Duss has endorsed, the new administration will seek radical changes in America's conduct abroad.

title: The Democrats' Israel Problem
summary: Sanders would be the first Jewish president, and the most hostile to the Jewish state.. Bernie Sanders would be the first Jewish president. He would also be the president most hostile to Israel.
